text: greetings from beautiful Oregon my wife
Marco and I have traveled cross-country
in the Volvo v60 cross country to go
well what else cross-country skiing
there's nothing wrong with your screen
these are snapshots to make our long
weekend an actual vacation I've ditched
the video camera no selfies I promise
yes the cross-country moniker is back
the original simply became xc70
a mouthful most owners ignore the larger
seventy will stick around compared to
the standard v60 cross country is raised
two point six inches for nearly eight
inches of ground clearance
there's a new grill wheel arch cladding
and serious commitment to the
resurrected name iView v60 is more of a
sleek hatchback than wagon fun fact the
V stands for versatile starting in
Seattle no cross rails are needed
stashing skis inside is easy they're
still seating for four naturally we've
over packed still everything fits under
the security shade a retractable
security Nats keeps luggage and pets
from flying forward active safety tech
starts as we back out of the drive with
cross path detection at this point we
both think the other has grabbed the bag
of phone charger stuff off the kitchen
table oh well
beautiful Pacific Northwest sites are
reason enough for a 350 mile drive those
fresh hotel waffles in the morning or
another maybe I like them too much
anyways
cross-country is aptly named the driving
dynamic isn't sporty that could be due
to the raised height but it's quiet
controlled and supremely comfortable for
long stretches even at altitude on steep
roads acceleration is no problem there's
one powertrain a turbocharged 2.5 liter
5 S 5 cylinder engine 250 horsepower and
266 pound feet of torque are on tap the
gearbox is a six-speed all four wheels
get motivation hill descent control
makes venturing down extremely steep
mountain roads easier Marco is petite at
5 feet tall visibility is good for her
except out the rear blind spot warning
helps and there's a visual cue if
sensors feel you're tailgating seats
aren't vented but might be the best in
the biz for long tracks after 200 miles
or so were fresh enough for a long hike
in the wilderness getting to the
trailhead means taking dirt roads found
in most state parks cross country is not
for severe off-roading rough Forest
Service roads are no problem in other
words you'll be parking next to Subarus
the Volvo is fairly efficient getting
here that's our average for those of you
unfamiliar to Oregon someone always
pumps the gas for you how civilized my
major pet peeve is the user interface
there are a lot of features including
Yelp and Pandora apps getting to them
using this little knob isn't much fun
the soft touch dashboard is a bit plain
but the rest of the interior is well
crafted with the usual Volvo touches
including a storage nook behind the
center stack in Bend we pick up friends
Beverly and Bill he takes the heated
wheel
it's his first experience with lane
departure warning and radar assisted
cruise control also intriguing the city
safety system that brakes automatically
most impacts with cars under 31 miles an
hour
bill simulates the pedestrian avoidance
system and in some cases it
automatically breaks for bicyclists to
nice acting bill take a bow
there's snow at Mount Bachelor though
conditions are icy that's my excuse and
I'm sticking to it
starting at 42 grand this one is 49 as
tested a good value up against
competitor Aldi all rode v60 cross
country lives up to the name the ride
home is as comfortable as it is scenic
